title: List of My Reading
text:
By James Ladyman and Karoline Wiesner
My final-year MSci project involved the study of a complex system, foreign exchange markets. Each individual currency was treated as a spin in the Ising model, and by applying E.T. Jaynes’s principle of maximum entropy, we discovered the structure of interactions between these entities. Remarkably, this simple model of magnetism can also describe the phase transitions of liquid-gas systems, as they fall into the same universality class. This model has even been extended to study how critical our brain is, giving rise to the field of the critical brain hypothesis. Therefore, many ideas during my research project were derived from neuroscience papers. The financial market and the brain: both are complex systems.
About a year ago, I read a paper published by James Ladyman, a professor of philosophy of science at Bristol, titled ‘What is a Complex System?’ (Ladyman, Lambert, and Wiesner 2013). As I started my PhD at Bristol, my second supervisor, Francesco, mentioned that he also published a book about complexity. It became clear to me that I should read this book.

Ladyman, James, James Lambert, and Karoline Wiesner. 2013. “What Is a Complex System?” European Journal for Philosophy of Science 3: 33–67.
Chapter 1 presents The Truisms of Complexity Science as follows:
1. More is different.
2. Nonliving systems can generate order.
3. Complexity can come from simplicity.
4. Coordinated behaviour does not require an overall controller.
5. Complex systems are often modelled as networks or information processing systems.
6. There are various kinds of invariance and forms of universal behaviour in complex systems.
7. Complexity science is computational and probabilistic.
8. Complexity science involves multiple disciplines.
9. There is a difference between the order that complex systems produce and the order of the complex systems themselves.
Features that are necessary and sufficient for which kinds of complexity and complex system are as follows:
1. Numerosity: complex systems involve many interactions among many components.
2. Disorder and diversity: the interactions in a complex system are not coordinated or controlled centrally, and the components may differ.
3. Feedback: the interactions in complex systems are iterated so that there is feedback from previous interactions on a time scale relevant to the system’s emergent dynamics.
4. Non-equilibrium: complex systems are open to the environment and are often driven by something external.
5. Spontaneous order and self-organisation: complex systems exhibit structure and order that arises out of the interactions among their parts.
6. Nonlinearity: complex systems exhibit nonlinear dependence on parameters or external drivers.
7. Robustness: the structure and function of complex systems is stable under relevant perturbations.
8. Nested structure and modularity: there may be multiple scales of structure, clustering and specialisation of function in complex systems.
9. History and memory: complex systems often require a very long history to exist and often store information about history.
10. Adaptive behaviour: complex systems are often able to modify their behaviour depending on the state of the environment and the predictions they make about it.

2024/9/27
Reading What is a Complex System? by James Ladyman and Karoline Wiesner. The purpose of reading is to understand how systems out of thermodynamic equilibrium (a feature of complex systems) relate to a wide range of concepts associated with complexity.
• There was a video that helped clarify what is meant by a Markov chain and a stochastic process being stationary: Markov Chains Clearly Explained! Part - 1. His other videos are helpful as well. For example, when I saw \(P_{ij}^{(n)} = A_{ij}^n\) from the n-Step Transition Matrix video (Part 3), it was quite surprising. However, the Part 5 video on hidden Markov models wasn’t very helpful, but reading the appendix in the book was sufficient.
• What I’ve felt from reading this book (currently at p.90) is that it presents a lot of different ideas and has interesting discussions on the history of science, but I only seem to get excited when it starts mentioning the brain. I’m not sure if I’m necessarily interested in quantifying complexity. From the Apple notes on 28/9/2024:
As I’m reading through What is a Complex System?, it seems that the description of a complex system arises as we have more representations at different scales of analysis. The concept of ‘complexity’ was destined to arise as the scientific era evolved.
Non-equilibrium systems arise because we define what systems are in thermodynamic equilibrium, which are idealisations.
Things that fail to be idealised fall into this dualistic concept: non-equilibrium.

2024/10/3
It took about two weeks to finish this book. It was an accessible read until I reached chapter 4, which was Measuring Features of Complex Systems. In the end, I’m glad that I read it, even though I somehow felt rushed to finish as there were other responsibilities to manage continuously, such as setting up clusters for my university Mac, teaching, office setup, etc. Most importantly, from now on, I am going to focus on reading material that is directly related to my project since it may give the impression to my supervisors that I’m not working hard. Reading a book like this takes a long time, as there are many new terms I had not encountered before.
Anyway, it was a good read. Would I buy a physical copy for myself? Maybe not, but it was a good one.

text:
2024/10/4 - Hydrophobicity Across Length Scales: The Role of Surface Criticality
By Mary Kathryn Coe

Q1. Resolved



On page 35, Chapter 2.1


I’m not entirely sure why the surface tension is defined in that way, as it’s normally considered force per unit area. So, I asked ChatGPT:


Click to reveal the answer!

The definition of surface tension in this context is derived from the thermodynamic perspective, which connects surface tension to the grand potential difference between a bulk fluid and a system with an interface. The reasoning follows these steps:

Grand Potential Definition: The grand potential, \(\Omega\), is given by: \[
\Omega = U - TS - \mu N
\] This expression is crucial for systems where particle number and volume are allowed to fluctuate, such as liquid-vapour interfaces.
Surface Tension from Thermodynamics: Surface tension, \(\gamma\), represents the energy cost per unit area to create an interface. In thermodynamic terms, this corresponds to how much the grand potential increases when introducing an interface between coexisting phases (liquid and vapour).
Difference between Bulk and Interface: The bulk grand potential, \(\Omega_b\), corresponds to a system without an interface (uniform bulk). When an interface is introduced, the grand potential changes, denoted as \(\Omega_{\text{ex}}\), the excess grand potential: \[
\Omega_{\text{ex}} = \Omega - \Omega_b
\]
Surface Tension as Excess Grand Potential per Unit Area: The surface tension is then defined as the excess grand potential per unit area, \(A\), required to form the interface: \[
\gamma = \frac{\Omega_{\text{ex}}}{A} = \frac{\Omega - \Omega_b}{A}
\] This formulation makes sense because surface tension describes the energetic cost to create a unit area of interface between two phases.

In summary, while surface tension is often discussed in terms of force per unit length in simpler mechanical contexts, in thermodynamics, it is expressed as the excess grand potential per unit area. This ties into how interfaces modify the system’s energy in comparison to the bulk. The two definitions are equivalent but applied in different contexts: mechanical (force/length) vs. thermodynamic (energy/area).



Derivation of equation 2.1.8, 2.1.9, 2.1.10

\[
\Omega_b(\mu, V, T) = U - TS - \mu N = -pV
\]
Taking the differential:
\[
d\Omega_b = d(U - TS - \mu N)
\]
Using the first law of thermodynamics:
\[
dU = TdS - pdV + \mu dN
\]
Differentiating \(TS\):
\[
d(TS) = TdS + SdT
\]
Differentiating \(\mu N\):
\[
d(\mu N) = \mu dN + N d\mu
\]
Substituting these into the differential for \(\Omega_b\):
\[
d\Omega_b = (TdS - pdV + \mu dN) - (TdS + SdT) - (\mu dN + N d\mu)
\]
Simplifying:
\[
d\Omega_b = -S_b dT - N_b d\mu - p dV
\]
For constant volume (\(dV = 0\)), the volume is assumed to remain constant because we are focusing on surface effects rather than bulk volume changes.:
\[
d\Omega_b = -S_b dT - N_b d\mu
\]
Now for equation (2.1.6):
\[
\Omega(\mu, V, T) = U - TS - \mu N = -pV + \gamma A
\]
Taking the differential:
\[
d\Omega = d(U - TS - \mu N + \gamma A)
\]
Substituting differentials:
\[
d\Omega = TdS - pdV + \mu dN - (TdS + SdT) - (\mu dN + N d\mu) + \gamma dA + A d\gamma
\]
Simplifying:
\[
d\Omega = -S dT - N d\mu + \gamma dA
\]
Now subtract:
\[
d\Omega - d\Omega_b = (-S dT - N d\mu + \gamma dA) - (-S_b dT - N_b d\mu)
\]
Simplifying:
\[
d\Omega - d\Omega_b = -(S - S_b)dT - (N - N_b)d\mu + \gamma dA
\]
This is equation (2.1.8).

From equation (2.1.7):
\[
\gamma = \frac{\Omega_{\text{ex}}}{A} = \frac{\Omega - \Omega_b}{A}
\]
Taking the differential:
\[
d\gamma = \frac{d\Omega_{\text{ex}}}{A} = \frac{d\Omega - d\Omega_b}{A}
\]
Now, use the result from equation (2.1.8):
\[
d\Omega - d\Omega_b = -(S - S_b) dT - (N - N_b) d\mu + \gamma dA
\]
So:
\[
d\Omega_{\text{ex}} = -s_{\text{ex}} A dT - \Gamma d\mu + \gamma dA
\]
where:

\(s_{\text{ex}} = \frac{S - S_b}{A}\) is the surface excess entropy per unit area,
\(\Gamma = N - N_b\) is the excess number of particles (adsorption).

Dividing through by \(A\), we get:
\[
\frac{d\Omega_{\text{ex}}}{A} = -s_{\text{ex}} dT - \frac{\Gamma}{A} d\mu + \gamma \frac{dA}{A}
\]
Now, using the fact that \(\gamma \frac{dA}{A}\) is small for constant area, we can ignore this term, giving:
\[
s_{\text{ex}} dT + \frac{\Gamma}{A} d\mu + d\gamma = 0
\]
This is equation (2.1.9).

Rearrange equation (2.1.9):
\[
\frac{\Gamma}{A} d\mu = -s_{\text{ex}} dT - d\gamma
\]
At constant temperature (\(dT = 0\)), this simplifies to:
\[
\frac{\Gamma}{A} d\mu = -d\gamma
\]
Now, dividing both sides by \(d\mu\), we get:
\[
\frac{\Gamma}{A} = -\left(\frac{\partial \gamma}{\partial \mu}\right)_T
\]
This is equation (2.1.10).

And I need to ask about equations 2.1.11 to 2.1.13, as I cannot find reference [40].


Q2. Resolved



On page 40, Chapter 2.3


I wasn’t sure what the one-particle density is or its use, so I asked ChatGPT:


Click to reveal the answer!

The one-particle density function, often denoted as \(\rho^{(1)}(\mathbf{r})\), represents the probability density of finding a particle at a specific position \(\mathbf{r}\) in a system of particles. It describes how particles are distributed in space on average and is a key observable in statistical mechanics and the study of fluids.
The equation given is:
\[
\hat{\rho}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r}) = \sum_{j=1}^{N} \delta(\mathbf{r} - \mathbf{r}_j)
\]
This is the one-particle density operator, and it has the following meaning:

Dirac Delta Function: \(\delta(\mathbf{r} - \mathbf{r}_j)\) is a Dirac delta function that ‘picks out’ the position of the \(j\)-th particle. It is equal to zero everywhere except at \(\mathbf{r}_j\), where it is infinite, ensuring that it integrates to 1. Thus, it counts the presence of a particle at \(\mathbf{r}_j\).
Summation over All Particles: The sum runs over all particles \(j\) from 1 to \(N\), so this operator adds up the contributions from all particles in the system, effectively counting the number of particles at position \(\mathbf{r}\).

In essence, the one-particle density operator \(\hat{\rho}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r})\) gives the total number of particles at position \(\mathbf{r}\) in the system. Since it is an operator, the actual one-particle density \(\langle \hat{\rho}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r}) \rangle\), as defined in equation (2.3.2), is obtained by averaging over all possible configurations of the system in the given ensemble (such as the grand canonical ensemble).
Why Does It Look Like This?
The form of equation (2.3.1) stems from how we represent the microscopic distribution of particles in space. The Dirac delta function ensures that for each particle, its position contributes to the overall density only at the exact location where that particle exists. This is a standard way to construct density operators in statistical mechanics because:

The delta function precisely pinpoints the position of a particle.
Summing over all particles ensures that the density operator accounts for the total number of particles present in the system.

This representation allows us to describe spatially inhomogeneous systems where the density may vary across different regions (e.g., near a surface or an external potential). For homogeneous fluids, where particles are evenly distributed, this density would reduce to a constant value (the bulk density \(\rho_b\)).
Summary
The one-particle density operator, \(\hat{\rho}^{(1)}(\mathbf{r})\), reflects how particles are distributed in space at a microscopic level. The delta functions track the positions of individual particles, and summing over all particles gives the total density at position \(\mathbf{r}\). The actual one-particle density function \(\rho^{(1)}(\mathbf{r})\) is then the ensemble average of this operator over all configurations of the system.



Q3. Resolved



On page 43, Chapter 2.3


I wasn’t sure why each variable is specifically chosen to form those equations. For example, in section 2.4.3, I do not understand why λ can be factored out of g on the right-hand side when λ has two different exponents, a and b. So, I asked ChatGPT:


Click to reveal the answer!

Starting with Equation (2.4.3):
\[
g(\lambda^a u, \lambda^b v) = \lambda g(u, v)
\]
This equation states that the function \(g(u, v)\) is a generalised homogeneous function. To understand why it takes this form and why \(\lambda\) appears outside the function on the right-hand side, let’s break this down:

Homogeneous Functions: A function is called homogeneous of degree \(\alpha\) if, when all its arguments are scaled by a factor \(\lambda\), the function itself scales by \(\lambda^\alpha\). Mathematically, for a homogeneous function \(f(x, y)\), we would have: \[
f(\lambda x, \lambda y) = \lambda^\alpha f(x, y)
\] This property is common in critical phenomena where we are dealing with power-law behaviour near critical points.
Generalised Homogeneous Functions: The function \(g(u, v)\) is a generalised homogeneous function because it allows different exponents for different variables. In this case, the variables \(u\) and \(v\) scale with different exponents \(a\) and \(b\) under the same scaling factor \(\lambda\).

\(\lambda^a u\): Here, \(u\) is scaled by \(\lambda^a\). This implies that \(u\) behaves differently under scaling compared to \(v\).
\(\lambda^b v\): Similarly, \(v\) is scaled by \(\lambda^b\).

Why \(\lambda\) can be factored out: The key to understanding why \(\lambda\) can be factored out on the right-hand side despite having different exponents for \(u\) and \(v\) lies in the definition of a generalised homogeneous function. By construction, we impose that when the variables are scaled in a particular way (with exponents \(a\) and \(b\)), the function scales by \(\lambda\) itself. This is a property we assign to \(g(u, v)\). It doesn’t mean that \(\lambda\) is constant; rather, the entire function \(g(u, v)\) is designed to respond to the scaling in this specific manner.
The exponents \(a\) and \(b\) control how \(u\) and \(v\) individually respond to scaling, but the overall response of the function is to scale as \(\lambda\). The scaling of the function on the right-hand side doesn’t contradict the fact that \(\lambda\) has different exponents inside the arguments. This is simply a mathematical constraint on how the function \(g(u, v)\) behaves under scaling.
In other words, the form: \[
g(\lambda^a u, \lambda^b v)
\] ensures that the function scales uniformly by \(\lambda\), despite the individual variables scaling differently.

Equation (2.4.4):
Now, let’s explain how this scaling idea applies to the singular part of the free energy in equation (2.4.4):
\[
\omega_{\text{sing}}(\delta \mu, t) = \lambda^{-d} \omega_{\text{sing}}(\lambda^a \delta \mu, \lambda^b t)
\]

Variables:

\(\delta \mu = \mu - \mu_{\text{co}}\) is the difference between the chemical potential \(\mu\) and the critical chemical potential \(\mu_{\text{co}}\).
\(t\) is the reduced temperature: \(t = \frac{T - T_c}{T_c}\).
\(d\) is the dimensionality of the system (important for scaling relations).

Applying the Scaling Relation: Here, the function \(\omega_{\text{sing}}\), which represents the singular part of the free energy, is assumed to be a generalised homogeneous function. This means it should follow a scaling law similar to the one introduced in equation (2.4.3).
The variables \(\delta \mu\) and \(t\) are scaled by \(\lambda^a\) and \(\lambda^b\), respectively, where \(a\) and \(b\) are scaling exponents that determine how \(\delta \mu\) and \(t\) change when scaled by \(\lambda\).
Why \(\lambda^{-d}\)?

The factor \(\lambda^{-d}\) appears because we are dealing with free energy, which is an extensive quantity. In thermodynamics, extensive quantities scale with the volume of the system, and in \(d\)-dimensional space, the volume scales as \(\lambda^d\). Since we are dealing with the singular part of the free energy, the scaling reflects the dimensionality of the system. The minus sign arises because, under scaling, the free energy decreases as the system grows larger.

The Free Choice of \(\lambda\): The scaling factor \(\lambda\) is arbitrary, meaning you can choose its value to simplify the equation. In this case, we choose \(\lambda^b = t^{-1}\), which simplifies the second argument (the temperature dependence) of \(\omega_{\text{sing}}\). By doing this, we reduce the complexity of the equation and make the temperature scaling explicit.

Equation (2.4.5):
This equation shows the final form after choosing \(\lambda^b = t^{-1}\):
\[
\omega_{\text{sing}}(\delta \mu, t) = t^{d/b} \omega_{\text{sing}}(t^{-a/b} \delta \mu, 1)
\]

Why this form? By setting \(\lambda^b = t^{-1}\), we have scaled out the temperature dependence in the second argument of \(\omega_{\text{sing}}\). This isolates the temperature dependence into the prefactor \(t^{d/b}\), while leaving a scaling function that depends only on the ratio \(\delta \mu / t^{a/b}\), which is now the only scaling variable.

\(t^{d/b}\): This represents how the singular part of the free energy depends on temperature near the critical point. The exponent \(d/b\) dictates how strongly the free energy diverges as \(t \to 0\) (the critical point).
\(\Sigma\left( \frac{\delta \mu}{t^{a/b}} \right)\): The function \(\Sigma\) is the scaling function, which encodes the remaining dependence on the scaled chemical potential \(\delta \mu / t^{a/b}\).


In Summary: - In equation (2.4.3), the exponents \(a\) and \(b\) control how the variables \(u\) and \(v\) scale. Despite their different scaling behaviours, the overall function scales by \(\lambda\) because it is designed as a generalised homogeneous function. - In equation (2.4.4), the singular part of the free energy near the critical point follows a similar scaling law, with the dimensionality \(d\) appearing as a factor to reflect the extensive nature of free energy. - In equation (2.4.5), we choose \(\lambda^b = t^{-1}\) to simplify the scaling form, making the dependence on temperature explicit and reducing the complexity of the equation. The resulting expression separates the prefactor \(t^{d/b}\) and leaves a scaling function that depends only on the ratio \(\delta \mu / t^{a/b}\), which captures the critical behaviour.



Fluctuations? One correlated entity?

In the context of phase transitions, particularly near a critical point, the term “fluctuations” refers to fluctuations in the local density of the system. Let’s explain in detail what this means, especially in the context of critical opalescence and long-range correlations.

Density Fluctuations: When we talk about “density” in this context, we mean the number density of particles in a given volume. In simple terms, it’s how densely packed the particles are in a particular region. The density can fluctuate due to thermal motion, and these fluctuations are typically small and localised in non-critical conditions.

However, as a system approaches the critical point of a phase transition (e.g., a liquid-vapour transition), the magnitude of these fluctuations grows dramatically.

What happens near the critical point?

Correlation Length (\(\xi\)): The correlation length \(\xi\) represents the distance over which particles in the system are correlated or “communicate” with each other. Normally, this length is finite, and beyond this distance, the properties of the system in one region do not affect another region.
Near the critical point, however, \(\xi \to \infty\). This means that particles separated by very large distances (even macroscopic scales) are correlated with each other. The entire system essentially becomes one correlated entity.
Diverging Fluctuations: As the correlation length grows, the fluctuations in the local density (i.e., how many particles are in a given region at any time) also grow larger. This happens because, when the correlation length is large, particles across large distances influence each other. As a result, fluctuations occur over all length scales, from small to very large.
Density Fluctuations: Specifically, these are fluctuations in the number of particles in a given volume. Imagine regions in a fluid where the particle density becomes temporarily higher or lower than the average. At the critical point, these fluctuations become very large and occur over very large distances, leading to the system appearing “cloudy” or “milky” — this is the phenomenon of critical opalescence.


What exactly is fluctuating? At the critical point, density is the key fluctuating quantity, but more generally, the term “fluctuations” can refer to:


Order Parameter Fluctuations: Near a critical point, there is typically an order parameter that characterises the phase transition. For example, in the liquid-vapour transition, this order parameter could be the difference in density between the liquid and vapour phases. As the system approaches the critical point, the fluctuations in the order parameter become large.
For example, in a fluid near the liquid-vapour critical point:

In the liquid phase, particles are densely packed.
In the vapour phase, particles are more spread out.

Near the critical point, there is no sharp distinction between liquid and vapour phases. Instead, the system fluctuates between states that resemble both phases. You might see a region that has the density of a liquid next to a region that has the density of a vapour, and these regions appear and disappear rapidly.


Why do these fluctuations occur? At the critical point, the system is in a delicate balance between two phases (e.g., liquid and vapour). The free energy landscape becomes very flat near the critical point, meaning that the system can fluctuate easily between different configurations with very little energy cost. These fluctuations span all length scales, leading to the phenomenon where large regions of the system can fluctuate in density.
Critical Opalescence: The critical opalescence mentioned in the text is a direct consequence of these large fluctuations in density. Light passing through the fluid is scattered by the density fluctuations. Since the fluctuations occur over a wide range of length scales (from very small to very large), they scatter light across all wavelengths, leading to the “milky” appearance of the fluid near the critical point.


Why does light scatter? Light is scattered by regions of varying density because the refractive index of the fluid depends on its density. When the density fluctuates significantly over large distances, light passing through the fluid encounters regions of different densities, leading to scattering in all directions.

Summary:

What is fluctuating near the critical point?: Primarily, the number density (i.e., the number of particles per unit volume) fluctuates near the critical point.
Why do these fluctuations grow?: As the correlation length \(\xi\) becomes large, regions of the system separated by large distances become correlated, allowing large-scale fluctuations in density.
What’s the physical manifestation?: These fluctuations lead to observable phenomena such as critical opalescence, where light is scattered by the large fluctuations in density, causing the fluid to appear milky or cloudy.

In short, the “fluctuations” near the critical point refer to density fluctuations, which are tied to the divergence of the correlation length, and these fluctuations grow larger and affect larger regions of the system as the critical point is approached.


From chapter 2.4.3, I decided to skim through this document as it became too technical to understand the entire thesis when it began with perturbation theory. Additionally, many concepts here are primarily from equilibrium statistical physics.






Note



Chapter 2.4.5: Wetting and Drying Phase Transitions is very well written and full of useful knowledge. For the next project meeting, let’s prepare a slide to go over this.

2024/10/2 Why are the clouds at the same height when I look at the cloudy sky?



View from Brandon Hill


When we observe clouds appearing at the same height, it’s often due to a phenomenon where a particular layer of the atmosphere has the right conditions for cloud formation. In the troposphere (the lowest layer of the atmosphere), clouds form when the air cools to its dew point, causing water vapour to condense into droplets or ice crystals. This typically happens at specific altitudes where temperature and pressure conditions are ideal for condensation.
Clouds that seem to form at the same height are likely part of the same atmospheric layer, known as a cloud base. The cloud base marks the altitude at which rising air reaches its dew point. If the conditions across the sky are uniform, we’ll see many clouds forming at roughly the same altitude, giving the illusion of a flat layer of clouds.
Cloud formation is fundamentally a non-equilibrium process. It results from dynamic atmospheric conditions like rising air currents, changes in temperature and pressure, and the continuous exchange of energy. These factors drive processes such as condensation and evaporation, which are inherently out of equilibrium. This aligns with the behaviour of active matter systems, where each particle consumes energy to move, keeping the system perpetually out of equilibrium.
To create an effective repulsion in our ABP simulations, we consider modifying the wall-fluid interactions to induce a torque that reorients particles away from the surface. One approach might be to introduce an anisotropic interaction potential near the wall. When an ABP approaches the surface, this potential could apply a torque that turns the particle’s propulsion direction away from the wall, effectively reducing its tendency to accumulate there.



2024/10/5 An idea of beginning the introduction
This thesis is ultimately about phase transitions. The central question is: what happens during a transition, for example, from water to ice, from a fluid to a superfluid, or from a paramagnet to a ferromagnet? The physics of such transitions is rich and complex. There are a number of different theoretical tools available to understand them. The study begins by examining thermodynamics and extends to the application of statistical mechanics to these transitions. Additionally, statistical field theory, a fully-fledged field theory similar to what is seen in particle physics or general relativity, will be applied. The goal is to use these approaches, along with concepts of symmetry and other properties, to understand different phases of matter.
For a long time, understanding phase transitions was a mystery, especially what’s known as a critical point. It’s an interesting situation: we have something as familiar as water, and it was not until the mid-20th century that significant progress was made. The phase behaviour of water can be examined using a pressure-temperature diagram:



Phase diagram of water (Cmglee n.d.)

Cmglee. n.d. “Phase Diagram of Water Simplified.” https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Phase_diagram_of_water_simplified.svg.



On the horizontal axis is temperature, and on the vertical axis is pressure.
The phase diagram for water features three regions: steam, water, and ice.
There’s a point called the triple point, where all three phases coexist, and a critical point, which marks the end of the liquid-gas boundary.

Water is essential, as most of us are mostly water, and yet the physics of what happens at this critical point wasn’t understood for the longest time. It’s a system that is incredibly close to us, yet to understand it requires some of the deepest ideas in physics, particularly the renormalisation group.
In this sense, phase transitions form a uniquely positioned subject. They are simultaneously very close to our everyday experience and yet require extremely deep ideas to understand properly. Most other areas of physics are typically far removed from daily life. Quantum mechanics operates on microscopic scales, and astrophysics on cosmological scales, both far from what can be intuitively grasped. But here, some really deep, beautiful puzzles are found in the world around us.

2024/10/8 Analytical Mechanics
I’ve been watching Tom’s lectures on Analytical Mechanics once more. I’ve just finished part 2. The topics are:

Calculus of variations
Lagrangian mechanics
Hamiltonian mechanics

Why did I start watching it?
Well, during the last project meeting, I had a naïve question about whether we could formulate a Lagrangian for the drying scenario. For example, in my supervisor’s papers, they couldn’t manage to observe the drying transition in their setup. So, I asked if, when the trajectory of all particles is away from the surface, we could possibly derive an analytical equation of forces between the particles and the wall to induce torque. Just a pure naïve idea.
Nigel mentioned that the principle of least action makes sense in equilibrium settings, so I had to revise that concept. The Lagrangian is the kinetic energy minus the potential energy, whatever this quantity is. In non-equilibrium systems, energy keeps changing since active agents continuously consume energy. Also, the effective potential depends on the properties of the wall. So, the Lagrangian would become time-dependent, which now makes sense based on what Nigel said.
The beautiful theorem was revisited from his lectures: Noether’s theorem.

If the laws of physics don’t depend on time, energy is conserved.
Similarly, if the system has translational or rotational invariance, momentum or angular momentum is conserved, respectively.

This is beautiful: conserved quantities derive from the symmetries of the system. It also implies that since energy is not conserved for the system I’m interested in, the equations of motion would be time-dependent. I think it would be useful to pay attention to how the equations of motion for active Brownian particles are formulated once I revise their papers.
As for his lectures, I’ll continue with part 3 since I’ve already watched the first two. That said, I remember his lecture notes being better than the video recordings, although his video lectures on phase transitions were much more inspiring. So, a note for my future self: when revising the content of the analytical formulation of mechanics, read his lecture notes.

2024/10/12 Making a presentation

Introduction
In this presentation, I’m going to explain the theoretical foundations of hydrophobicity by examining wetting and drying phase transitions. The phenomena are driven by surface tension and critical temperature scaling.


Young’s Equation
Consider a droplet of liquid on a surface. The contact angle, denoted as θ, quantifies the affinity between the liquid and the surface. This angle is determined by resolving the surface tensions of the interfaces involved. The relationship is given by Young’s equation:
\[
\cos \theta = \frac{\gamma_{sv} - \gamma_{sl}}{\gamma_{lv}} \tag{1}
\]
Where: - \(\gamma_{sv}\) is the surface-vapour tension - \(\gamma_{sl}\) is the surface-liquid tension - \(\gamma_{lv}\) is the liquid-vapour tension

Hydrophobic vs Hydrophilic

Hydrophobic surfaces: \(90^\circ < \theta < 180^\circ\)
Hydrophilic surfaces: \(0^\circ < \theta < 90^\circ\)

At two extremes:

\(\theta = 0^\circ\): Full wetting.
\(\theta = 180^\circ\): Perfect drying.




Surface Phase Transitions
The approach to the two limiting cases represents surface phase transitions—wetting for \(\theta = 0^\circ\) and drying for \(\theta = 180^\circ\).

Cahn’s Scaling Law
Cahn’s theory explains the scaling behaviour of surface tensions as the critical temperature \(T_c\) is approached (see: (Cahn 1977)). The surface tension vanishes following the power law:

Cahn, John W. 1977. “Critical Point Wetting.” The Journal of Chemical Physics 66 (8): 3667–72.
\[
\gamma_{lv} \sim (-t)^\mu \quad \text{with} \quad \mu = (d-1)\nu
\]
For a fluid with \(d = 3\), the critical exponent is \(\nu \approx 0.63\), yielding \(\mu \approx 1.26\).


Contact Angle Near \(T_c\)
As \(T_c\) is approached, the contact angle vanishes:
\[
\cos \theta \sim t^{\beta - \mu} \quad \text{with} \quad \beta \approx 0.33
\]
Thus, \(\cos \theta\) diverges as \(t^{-0.93}\), but is constrained to \(|\cos \theta| \leq 1\).

Why \(\beta - \mu\)?
Near the critical temperature, both \(\gamma_{sv}\) and \(\gamma_{sl}\) vanish. As \(T\) approaches \(T_c\), \(\gamma_{lv}\) tends to zero as \((-t)^\mu\). The numerator \(\gamma_{sv} - \gamma_{sl}\) scales with the order parameter difference \(\Delta \rho = \rho_l - \rho_v\), because the distinction between liquid and vapour phases diminishes. This gives:
\[
\gamma_{sv} - \gamma_{sl} \sim (-t)^\beta
\]
By substituting the scaling behaviours of \(\gamma_{lv}\) and \(\gamma_{sv} - \gamma_{sl}\) into Young’s equation, we get:
\[
\cos \theta \sim \frac{(-t)^\beta}{(-t)^\mu} = t^{\beta - \mu}
\]




Wetting and Drying Transitions
The phase transition occurs at a specific temperature:

Wetting occurs at \(T_W\), where \(\cos \theta = 1\).
Drying occurs at \(T_D\), where \(\cos \theta = -1\).

At these temperatures, a macroscopic layer of liquid or vapour forms at the surface.

Critical vs First-Order Transitions
The nature of these transitions can be:

Critical: The equilibrium film width \(\ell_{eq}\) grows continuously as \(T_D\) is approached.
First-order: The film width jumps discontinuously.

Below are illustrations of critical and first-order transitions for drying:

# Insert visual figure using code or links to diagrams




Predrying Transitions
In systems undergoing first-order drying, predrying can occur at temperatures \(T > T_D\). In this case, the vapour film transitions from a thin to a thick layer before the full drying transition at \(T_D\).

Scaling Behaviour
The equilibrium film width \(\ell_{eq}\) exhibits different behaviours depending on the order of the transition:
\[
\ell_{eq} = \frac{-\Gamma}{A_{sv} \Delta \rho}
\]
Where:

\(\Gamma = \int \mathrm{d}r \, [\rho(r) - \rho_b]\) is the adsorption, which describes the excess of fluid near the surface relative to the bulk.
\(A_{sv}\) is the surface area of the substrate-vapour interface
\(\Delta \rho = \rho_l - \rho_v\) is the difference between the liquid and vapour densities

For \(\rho(r)\), we know from the statistical mechanics of fluids that the one-particle density \(\rho^{(1)}(r)\) can be written in the form of an ensemble average.:
\[
\langle \hat{\rho}^{(1)}(r) \rangle = \frac{1}{\Xi} \sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{e^{\beta \mu N}}{\Lambda^{3N}(N-1)!} \int \mathrm{d}r^{N-1} e^{-\beta[\Phi(r^N) + V_{\text{ext}}(r^N)]}
\]
This defines the fluid’s spatially varying density at a microscopic level.

title: Project Description
text:
In terms of the project on ‘Active Drying’, drying is an equilibrium surface phase transition that occurs when a fluid at liquid-vapour coexistence is in contact with an infinite planar substrate that is sufficiently weakly attractive to the fluid particles, such that the vapour phase prefers to be at the substrate. Surface phase transitions can be first-order or critical, and previous results (see [1, 2]) show that drying is generally a critical surface phase transition.
Previous work on ABPs has shown that they can exhibit a first-order wetting transition (see [3]). This effect has been investigated by looking at liquid-vapour ‘slabs’ and droplets, showing consistent results. However, the mechanism by which the wetting transition is traversed does not seem to allow for the possibility of a drying transition. To have a chance of observing this, we need to understand the mechanism by which ABPs interact with a surface.
The aggregation effect at a hard wall arises because ABPs become trapped at the wall and cannot diffuse away quickly enough. The project will attempt to induce a drying transition by coupling the ABP velocity vector to the wall-fluid interaction in such a way as to produce a torque that creates an effective wall-fluid repulsion, possibly enabling a drying transition. Our task will be to modify a standard MD simulation package to introduce this torque and then proceed similarly to the Turci and Wilding paper in PRL 2021 (see [4]), to try to observe a drying transition. If evidence for this is seen, then we will try to quantify the character of the transition and analyse its critical properties.

In this presentation, we explore the theoretical underpinnings of hydrophobicity by examining wetting and drying phase transitions. The phenomena are driven by surface tension and critical temperature scaling, providing insights into surface phase transitions across different substrates.
